Build failed

- dsvm-glance http://207.189.188.190/logs/29/693129/6/check-not-vote/ext-glance-zuul/67e34d5 : FAILURE in 15m 55s

Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Comment inline about moving two of the policy definitions.

The tasks test failures require https://review.opendev.org/693952

Not sure, but you may also need https://review.opendev.org/693951 so that the tests will run reliably.

The PropertyRules tests may require some finessing with the policy enforcer.  (Glance uses the oslo policy engine to enforce ACLs on individual image properties; it doesn't make sense for these to have defaults.)  The failures are caused by oslo_policy.policy.PolicyNotRegistered exceptions.  I haven't had time to look into these.

Patch Set 6:

@Zane: Here's an outline of the problems we'll face trying to align the Glance policies with the rest of OpenStack: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/528021/

Patch Set 6:

Yeah, I read that spec and it certainly blocks getting the documentation into code (which is part of the goal), but not getting the policies defined in code (which is the part that is blocking future project-wide goals, and also a pre-requisite to you changing the policies around).

Patch Set 6:

To address the failure in glance.tests.unit.test_policy.TestPolicyEnforcer:

I think you'll need to remove test_policy_file_get_image_default_nobody and test_policy_file_get_image_default_everybody.  Those test what happens on image-show when there's only the "default" policy defined.  With the policies defined in code, I believe this isn't possible any more (that is, that there is no policy associated with "image_get" action).

Patch Set 6:

Wait, does that mean that the defaults for each policy should be "rule:default" rather than ""?

I'm confused at what those DEFAULT_POLICIES are for in general since they're not referenced anywhere. e.g. why does "publicize_image" default to "role:admin" and not "rule:context_is_admin", and what is the purpose of defining the context_is_admin rule when it's not used?
Uploaded patch set 7.
Uploaded patch set 8.

Patch Set 8:

> Wait, does that mean that the defaults for each policy should be
> "rule:default" rather than ""?

No, I don't think so.  Those tests were added when we changed "default":"" to "default":"role:admin" in the policy file, I guess to illustrate what happens when the "default" action is the only policy mentioned in the policy file.  If we make the default for each policy "rule:default" and then had "default":"role:admin" in the DEFAULT_POLICIES, operators would be forced to configure a policy file to allow end users to do anything, which I think goes against the sensible defaults in code idea?

> I'm confused at what those DEFAULT_POLICIES are for in general since
> they're not referenced anywhere. e.g. why does "publicize_image"
> default to "role:admin" and not "rule:context_is_admin", and what
> is the purpose of defining the context_is_admin rule when it's not used?

context_is_admin is used to set an is_admin flag on the context object, where it's used at various points to decide things like "should this user be allowed to see images in a project they don't belong to?" for which there aren't policies.  So like you'd expect from the name, it defines the administrative context.

I'm not sure exactly why we prefer "role:admin" in the policy file, probably just for simplicity.

Patch Set 8:

OK, cool, that aligns with what I independently figured out, and it's reflected in the latest patchset (removed the default rule + tests for it, and documented the is_admin_context rule).

Patch Set 8: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

Patch Set 9:

Patch Set 9:

> We cannot just silently ignore "default" rule that applies everywhere and has been the basis for any sane policy file so far.

That's only true if you look at Glance in isolation.  For all the other major services, using "default" in this way became impossible in Queens.  No one's been able to use an abbreviated file like the one you illustrated above for OpenStack services in general since Pike, so I don't think it's plausible that operators would expect to be able to use the "default" rule as the basis of any sane policy file so far.  Since Queens, operator expectations (for all the other services, anyway) have been that you can run without a policy file and have sane defaults, and if you want anything different, you have to run with a custom file, but you only need to mention the policies that you want to behave differently from the default behavior.  Actions that go unmentioned in the file are expected to behave according to the sane default defined in the code, not according to the "default" policy.

Patch Set 9:

Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 9:

One thing we could do is to reinstate the 'default' rule but with the check_str set to "", then change the check_str of all of the non-admin default rules to "rule:default". If we did that then your example:

  {
    "context_is_admin": "role:admin",
    "default": "role:admin",
    "get_image": "",
    "get_images": "",
    "download_image": "",
    "get_image_location": ""
  }

would work as expected. However, if a user relied on the default 'default' for some of their defaults (!), like so:

  {
    "context_is_admin": "role:admin",
    "get_image": "",
    "get_images": "",
    "download_image": "",
    "get_image_location": ""
  }

then that would not work the same as before; they'd still get the default "" policy on those rules with non-admin default that they did not specifically override, whereas previously the default 'default' was "role:admin".

(Glance and Keystone seem to be the only projects that used an admin-only rule as the default 'default' rule.)
